answer_html: Even though \(f''(x)\) is not defined at \(x = 0\).
answer_latex:
Even though $f''(x)$ is not
defined at $x = 0$.
hints_html: We already computed the second derivative in part (c). Checking where this is positive tells you when your function is concave up.

hints_raw: We already computed the second derivative in [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH100/December 2011/Question 5 (c)|part (c)]]. Checking where this is positive tells you when your function is concave up.
question: 5 (d)
sols_html:
From part (c), we know that

\[\begin{aligned} f''(x) &= \frac{6(x-4)}{25x^{9/5}}\end{aligned}\]

Notice that the potential inflection points are at x=0,4, where \(f''(x)\) is either zero or undefined. Doing a sign chart for this function yields the following. When x < 0 we have that \(f''(x) > 0\). When \(0 < x < 4\) we have that \(f''(x) < 0\). When \(x > 4\) we have that \(f''(x) > 0\). Hence, the function is concave up on \((-\infty, 0) \cup (4,\infty)\).

Note: Since the sign of \(f''(x)\) changes at both points, both \(x=0\) and \(x=4\) are inflection points. Even though \(f''(x)\) is not defined at \(x = 0\).
sols_latex:
From
{part
(c)}, we know that

\begin{align*}
f''(x) &= \frac{6(x-4)}{25x^{9/5}}
\end{align*}

Notice that the potential inflection points are at \emph{x}=0,4, where
$f''(x)$ is either zero or undefined. Doing a sign chart for this
function yields the following. When \emph{x \textless{} 0} we have that
$f''(x) > 0$. When $0 < x < 4$ we have that $f''(x) < 0$. When $x > 4$
we have that $f''(x) > 0$. Hence, the function is concave up on
$(-\infty, 0) \cup (4,\infty)$.

\emph{Note: Since the sign of $f''(x)$ changes at both points, both
$x=0$ and $x=4$ are inflection points. Even though $f''(x)$ is not
defined at $x = 0$.}
sols_raw:
From [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH100/December 2011/Question 5 (c)|part (c)]], we know that

:<math>\begin{align}
f''(x) &= \frac{6(x-4)}{25x^{9/5}}
\end{align}</math>

Notice that the potential inflection points are at ''x''=0,4, where <math>f''(x)</math> is either zero or undefined.  
Doing a sign chart for this function yields the following. When ''x < 0'' we have that <math>f''(x) > 0</math>. When <math> 0 < x < 4 </math> we have that <math>f''(x) < 0</math>. When <math> x > 4 </math> we have that <math>f''(x) > 0</math>. Hence, the function is concave up on <math>(-\infty, 0) \cup (4,\infty) </math>.

''Note: Since the sign of <math>f''(x)</math> changes at both points, both <math>x=0</math> and <math>x=4</math> are inflection points. Even though <math>f''(x)</math> is not defined at <math>x = 0</math>.''
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.

Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y=f(x)=6x^{1/5}+x^{6/5}\end{aligned}\]


Find the intervals on which y=f(x) is concave up.
statement_raw:

Find the intervals on which ''y=f(x)''  is concave up.
